title.rendered: Finding Love in the Right Places

content.rendered:
Trying to get tech to work can seem like getting a three year old to clean up his room.  Yet, tech doesn’t have the advantage of being loved, which makes it all the more frustrating when we can’t get it to do what we want.  

I don’t know about you, but my frustrations range from phones that mysteriously turn on, open an app and begin doing whatever it pleases.  Usually, I can tell that my phone is on because it warms up in my pocket.  By the time I notice it, however, the batter has drained half its power.

Software can be another problem. While Adobe offers some of the best software, it can also be some of the most frustrating.  Presently, I’m trying to get my computer connected to the internet, but its being very trying.  

Love is so important; it should be included in the list of things that we need in order to survive.  Like water, air and shelter, love might just be key to survival.  And though it may not be necessary for every individual, it is for the survival of the human race.  

Yes, we can survive without love, but we cannot thrive without it.  And though we can just survive, the better option is to thrive.  

Can we find love if and when we are alone?  I think so.  Why, you may ask?   Or, how?  It’s simple.  If you can find someone else who needs love and, if you are willing to be open and vulnerable, you can find love.  

First Corinthians 13 reminds us that, if we don’t have love, our actions, our very lives are useless.  For the Bible tells us that God, Himself, is love.  We love because He first loved us.  

If love is so important, how do we find it?  First, search for God.  You can “ask Him into your heart.”  It’s kind of like giving God your heart.  God already owns everything.  We just have to surrender our will to His.  

Second, we can decide to meet others where they are.  Activity look to help others, meeting then where they are and not where we wish they were.  God met us where we were when He sent Jesus to die on a cross.  We meet Him when we accept His gift.
